repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Third Emergency
            Services Support Project (ESSP 3)

abstracts.cdata!:
This Emergency Project Paper seeks the
            approval of the Executive Directors to provide a grant to
            the West Bank and Gaza for a proposed Third Emergency Social
            Service Support Project (ESSP 3). The will help finance the
            continued provision of essential social services during the
            on-going protracted crisis in the West Bank and Gaza. The
            main project outcomes are to: (a) maintain essential public
            education, health and social care facilities operational;
            (b) promote greater synergies among donor-funded emergency
            projects in the social sectors; (c) leverage additional
            donor resources to be channeled through the next phase of
            the ESSP multi-donor trust fund; and (d) underpin
            discussions on sector development by maintaining a policy
            dialogue in the social sectors.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Emergency Services
            Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is unlikely;
            institutional development impact is modest; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is satisfactory.
            Cited from this project include: 1) An operation focused on
            fast disbursement and without explicit developmental
            objectives is an efficient and effective vehicle to respond
            to emergency and crisis situations. Any conditionality or
            reform requirements, as well as explicit capacity-building
            components, risk disrupting the flow of critical financial
            resources, endanger adequate service provision, and
            undermine the functioning and credibility of the public
            agency. 2) Delegation of implementation responsibility to
            the relevant units in participating agencies and line
            ministries leads to more effective and efficient
            implementation. 3) Close supervision, in particular though
            field-based staff, and flexibility in adopting the program
            to local realities, as well as quickly responding to urgent
            needs and changing requirements by reallocating resources,
            are important elements in ensuring success in emergency
            operations.4) Ensure that implementing agency staff
            understand Bank requirements for implementation. Even under
            emergency conditions, delays can be reduced by using
            field-based Bank procurement staff to build local capacity,
            setting up training programs, and establishing a central
            oversight mechanism with the Borrower. 5) Explore
            alternatives to monitoring outputs and, whenever possible,
            identify and monitor outcome indicators. However, emphasize
            choosing readily observable or available indicators for
            monitoring and use. 6) Multi-Donor Trust Funds offer a more
            suitable arrangement for managing large donor-financed operations.
